editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.p: A comedy, as it hath been presented with good applause at the private house in drury-lane.
London. Printed by T. C. for William Cooke, and are to be sold by James Becket, in the inner temple. 1640.

div.head: A catalogue of such things as hath been published by James Shirley gent.

list.item: Changes, or love in a maze.
Comachio, an old lord, uncle to Depazzi.
Laura, a young gentlewoman great in favour.

sp.speaker: Volterre.
sp.l: Remember where you are,

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: That ever man
Should be so dull of soul to love a woman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: What in the name of fury hath made you
An enemy to that sex, upon what lady
False beyond Cressida, didst thou lose thy patience?
Find it again for shame, thou wert not born
A woman hater.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: No, I thank heaven
My mother's dead, and all my sisters, I
Had a contention in my nature, when
They were alive, but tie of blood prevailed
Against my disposition, I confess
I never wished them dead.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: How hadst thou been
Alive, but for thy mother?

sp.speaker: Ors,
sp.l: That's one reason
Should make our love the less to 'em, they do
But bring's acquainted with the world, which at
Our birth we are afraid of, and grow old
but to repent we are not embrois still,
Or things lost in conception.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: We may
As well condemn our fathers, and declaim
'Gainst them for our begetting, come Orseollo,
Desist to be a satire, I hope you would not
The Duchess should hear this; collect yourself
You are ith' presence, put on a smooth face
And speak court language, let me counsel you
To softness; what a courtier and so rugged?
Princes they say have many cares, and 'tis
Not less than treason, in a woman's court
To be so violent against 'em, these
Hangings may eavesdrop us.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Let 'em, let 'em,
May be 'twould move the Duchess to exempt me
From my attendance; and she knew my mind
She would allow me a writ of ease, lest I
Infect her court with railing 'gainst her sex:
I'd rather hear a mandrake, then let in
The noise of women; heaven that I might never
Converse with any.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Thou wilt never marry.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Marry? I'll first engender with a viper,
Were there but one woman alive, and but
By knowing her, no hope to stock the world
Again, I'd geld myself.

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Pity thou shouldst
Marry, to get a son that should been like thee;
Take heed least women for this bitterness
Make thee not first an eunuch, but we ha' lost
Our first discourse, thy passion like a storm
Hath quite transported us, from the Duke Foscari,
That hath now left us, let's
A cold suit with the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: If I stay
I shall talk treason, a cold suit? for ever
Ice dwell within their marrows can affect 'em,
he was too worthy on her.

sp.speaker: Vol,
sp.l: He deserved,
I know not what to think out, 'tis the third
Prince, that our duties have commended,
In hope to be made happy with her issue:
Nay, nay, have truce a little with thy spleen,
And let's talk wisely, we shall be observed;
I wonder.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: So do I.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: At what?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: At nothing,
At a woman, how 'tis possible a man
Should court and love 'em so, but now I think one,
I do not wonder.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: They are
All Circe's, and do steal away our souls;
They juggle us into shapes and puppets lovers.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: They ha' not juggled you methinks .

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Volterre and Orseollo, morrow to ye,
You hear the news.
Foscari is departed.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: In a mist, is he not? here's but we three,
The Duchess is a strange woman.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Contarini hast any other faith,
Are they not all so Volterre?
Thou hast been a traveler, and conversed
With the antipodes, almost put a girdle
About the world, taken dimensions
Of every nature, tasted all airs, and canst
Distinguish 'em to an atom, tell me signior
And be not partial to the sex, didst ever
Upon thy honour meet with such a creature,
We here call virtuous woman, are not all
The stock of 'em inconstant?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Nay let's ha'
no more invectives signior Orseollo
Traduce not all for some, it must be granted.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: They are an excellent creation, though
Some few decline from virtue, I've a wife,
I'm but new married neither, yet I dare
Boast my opinion.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Do not, the moon
Is yet but ith' first quarter Contarini,
I would endear my thoughts to thee, and thou
Wert not married, boast thy opinion.
Go sacrifice to sleep, why these are women
Will cozen a strong faith, cuckold their husbands,
Yet taken in the act persuade 'em into
A belief they do but dream so.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior
You're pleasant.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Pleasant

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As his gall will suffer him,
He has been casting out up this half hour,
Yet there is some behind still, if you name
A woman, he takes fire like touchwood, but
To the Duke Foscari.

sp.speaker: Ors,
sp.l: I have it,

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Ye talk

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I ha' the cause hen went away so soon.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Prithee enrich our knowledge, why?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I honour him.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: So we do all.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: He is a brave Duke, a man,
And in that, more than all his titles make him,
Some easy natures would ha' languished for her,
And ha' been paler than ye mean, with watching
Distilled their brain, tired, yea some to seem
Commit idolatry, given her their souls,
And changed 'em to her motion; in each window
Bescratching with some diamond her name,
and warm it so with kisses till it thaw
The very glass, which weeps itself away
In pity of the dotage, been content
To ha' worn their youth away in expectation;
This prince was wiser, he left Parma to
Behold a creature was cried up, the miracle
Of nature, a new star like Cassiopeia
That drew the eyes of Italy, and left 'em
Fixed in the admiration, but he needing
No Jacob's staff to take the height, and looking
With a true eye upon this wonder, found
She was a woman, nothing but a woman,
His wisdom quickly taught him to return
A shamed of his credulity.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: He's mad,
What a wild passion like a torrent, bears him
Against the women, 'tis well your hate
Points at the general, one woman's anger
Would check your forward — else
Contarini.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I dare not hear him talk more, we shall be
Held cherishers of his railing humour, in, in,
Prithee let's leave him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Why signior, are you so transported
You have not power enough to seem calm,
What dost at court?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Not cringe as you, and adore the nods
Of painted ladies, weary my hams to answer
Madams half curtsies, I ne'er come to court
But to defend me from it.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: The truth is,
I would be fain discharged, 'tis a hell to me,
There are so many wormed in't: would the Duchess
Would banish me into some wilderness,
I should endure the beasts though they devoured men,
I hate no monsters but the harpies.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Harpies have women's faces Contarini,
Yet now I think Volterre I have heard
There's another feminine murderer
Called the hyena, that invites men forth
To be devoured; you've heard how the Egyptian
Crocodile weeps, when death itself lies bathing
Within her tears, think but upon women
And tell me which I should avoide-first.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I seem a merit nigh, and I hope
You will deserve the favour, we are not
Wont to admit of servants near their person,
Without more caution.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It makes my bond
Of duty and observance greater.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My lord Comachio.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Let me employ some of your care upon
My nephew, something you may add
To improve him, you shall till no barren ground,
Though he reward you not with fruitfulness,
I shall have power to make you think your studies
Well placed.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your compass I shall sail by.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Contarini how's the day?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Not early.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Signior Orseollo, I know what cloud
Muffles your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He is constant to his humour.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Not the Duchess, come faith yet Orseollo,
We shall entreat you join with us to the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Yes, heigh! —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: So, so, he would but trouble us.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My lords, we must be circumspect,
We are not to negotiate a design
That looks but at the profit of one man:
The duchy calls to own it, all our cares
You know have met, that we might move the Duchess
To exchange her dull virginity for marriage;
Foscari whom our ambition pointed at, is lost
And he in some disgust gone hence.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I fear so.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: His violent departure gives us more
Than jealousy, we must solicit her,
But so as shall become our duties, and
Express our knowledge of her great soul
And pregnant wit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: She enters signior Comachia, 'tis referred
To your delivery.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Comachio! we have no knowledge of thy age,
But what thy wisdom and experience doth
Discover, is't not troublesome, t'attend
A young court?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Your grace so desires my duty, that I
Delight in service.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Contarini i'th morning's eyen, reveals
More youth, than he did by Hymen's tapers;
Looks younger than when we call him bridegroom.
Censure him Laura.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Your highness knows he hath a young wife.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: All my use of time, is but to perfect
My obedience to your excellence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We cherish both your loves, and you Volterre
Are great too within our memory.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I shall endeavour new merits.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The cause of your attendance now, is known
Ere you deliver it. The departure
Of the young Duke (Our lover) from our court
In so obscure a way, without your notice;
Our consent published gives you just cause
Of wonder: yet so much you're skilled both in
Our soul and nature, that no immediate
Motive of his anger shall be laid to
Our charge; but what you think, makes our person
Safe, and great.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: We come with humble modesty t'require
so much, as shall concern our care, both
Of your gracious self, and our good country.
Foscari, Duke of Parma is a great prince;
Feature; a lady, like your excellence,
His youth and strength may promise issue even
To a matron.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We know he merits all his praise. Proceed
To what you call your business.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: His Catholic majesty did lately by
His lieger, urge a title to this duchy,
And desire your counsel, he might be named
Your highness next, and lawful heir, unless
From your own person, were derived a prince
To intercept his hopes, with ease, you may
Consider, how unkind our fate will be,
Beyond his own natural soil, doth make
Obedience bondage.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You have yet hope, 'tis in my power
To prevent what you suspect.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: We have, but time (The enemy to lie,
And to increase) may scorn, destroy that hope.
If not for propitious love to us;
Yet for your own sake, your glory, hasten
The cure of these our fears: time is the moth
Of nature, devours all beauty, when those
Bright eyes, that govern now with phoebus-like
Predominance, shall yield no light unto
That darkened sky (Your face) some aged mother
Proud of her fertile womb, will show you then
Her offspring. Behold (Quoth she) I need no
Marble house for my fame to dwell in, these
Are my living monuments, but your sullen
Chastity, will not permit your fame to outlive
Your breath.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: No more Comachio! these are my own thoughts:
Shortly you shall see I am art, prevention
Of all danger.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: You are my gracious mistress.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Yea you shall much divulge your clemency
If to stifle public noise you reveal
The reason; why Foscari was not made
Your choice.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Foscari is a foreigner: born in
A climate not so temperate as ours,
And I am yet to know, whether his mind
Be different from such as please me here
At home: foreign alliance is an old
Disguise for Sunice's hatred: it charms the
Peaceful into a dull security;
Until the furious find best advantage
To make his anger known: than both are more
Engaged t'inflame, what erst th' one did kindle.
I should sin my good lords, if I did think
My humility disgraced my honour,
When I supposed my own court able to
Breed a man, fit to mingle blood, even with
A Princess; should I say with mine: what amazed,
Why does it want example, I should not
Think my choice would much accuse my eyes, if
I elect a lover here: unless some
Are more desertless than I am guilty of, Laura!
sp.stage: Exeunt Duchess, attendance. They first gaze on one another, then walk up and down.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Join to us Oedipus, yet we shall want
Help t'expound this riddle —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A lover here from her own court, sure it
Must be from this number, signior Volterre!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: My very good lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You are the man, the stars dance to. The spheres
Do practise music, only to make you
Merry, you are he signior.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Who, I my lord?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Do not conceal your hopes: they'll be worthy
Your acknowledgement; you would be installed
Ith' dark, steal titles, without the notice
Of the heralds, but noise attends honour.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I need a comment to your words.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Come, you young men are all temptation;
You have the purple veins (Signior) that swell
With wanton pride, and ladies' judgements are
Much governed by their eyes; what grace, what favour,
Did the Duchess lately show you, the more
T'endear your duty? hah?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I want a soul (Signior) if she ever
Honoured me with any phrase; but what is
Usual in her compliment tother lords.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is't possible —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: He has discovered somewhat that concerns
My joy. Nature needs no excuse why a
Duchess should affect a travailed lord;
You are great too, within our memory.
These were her words. hum! —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Signior Contarini.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: You observed the Duchess language?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Am I not thinking on't? heart, why do ye
Interupt me? —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: How's this my lord Volterre?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Your pleasure signior!

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: You have a fortunate skill in translation
Of mysterious language: I pray lend me
Your censure upon the last words the Duchess
Uttered.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Ha signior? they concern not me, I am
Forgotten by my stars, ay, Volterre
Is lost to all eyesight, but his own.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Do our brains melt this hot weather. These men
Were heretofore discreet, and now they talk
A if they had no eyelids, like things that
Never slept. I find the cause.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Quoth she, he looks younger, than when he stood
By Hymen's tapers, good, very good, I have
Oh were I single now; my wife, my wife;
She ruins all this hope. —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Since I have travelled, brought from France, the nice
Amorous cringe, that so enchants ladies:
'Tis fit I use it often, the tongue is
Powerful too, and I enrich in languages,
It shall be known —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior Volterre.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: To bring revel ▪ in the court, that's the way,
I have myself an able chine, and I
Can frisk like a goat: which females call
A lucky symptom — signior Contarini,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Your lop. must excuse me, I'm a little
Serious.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: O for a sight of Jupiter's wardrobe
That I might imitate the shape, in which
He courted Diana!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior Volterre.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I my lord that's my name, I'll go write
It down, lest this business make me forget it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Rebellious blood! must I neëds marry? had
I but delayed my lust a month, I might
Have wasted then my strength and nature, to
A nobler purpose: beget princes, now
I am in bondage to my marriage vow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My wife must do't and than I may effect
My hope with the great Duchess as soon as he
Most proud of demerits. Dandalo
Where's your lady.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Your lordship may hear both her voice and lute,
She's in the garden with Reollo your
Musician.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Hear, does she so much despair of long life,
That she need flatter her soul to tarry here
With soft airs, and wanton music.

sp.speaker: Danda.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Conduct her hither.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I saw your entrance, you bring news from court,
Let me share in't.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I must work her to it with art and leisure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What does your lop say?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sweet lend me thy ear in private — can I
Demand a thing from her that slumbered in
My bosom, and she be so unkind
To give my suit a hard repulse.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My lord I am not guilty of a cause
That can warrant your suspect either of
My love or duty.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I believe thee (Dear Carintha) but this
Injunction is so severe and strange, 'twill
Puzzle thy consent at first.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir make it known, I cannot be so slow
In any performance of your will, as you
Are to reveal it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thy breath is sweeter than the smoke ascending
From the phoenix funeral pile, I could
Kiss thee, even engender on thy lips.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You were not wont to be thus pleased, show me
Which way I may requite your passion, speak
The suit you talk on.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Now I know the strength of thy affection,
I slight my suit the grave will prove too easy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What is it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I'll have thee only kill thyself, cruch, thou
Shalt do it, hah —

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sir I suspect your health, you were not wont
To show your speech so much estranged from reason.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is this your love, your forward kindness?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Scarce has the moon expired a change since you
Received me in your bed a cold virgin;
Are you so soon tired with sacred marriage,
Desirous to motive my eternal
absence and by a means so cruel sir,
How have I deserved your hatred, or please
But to reveal the profit which by death
Can bring you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have not leisure to reply to your
Demands, will you do't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You fright my soul.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Orseollo happy you, whose frozen nature
Will not permit a closure with a woman.
The sex do quite degenerate from those
Great patterns which the former age produced.
Portia swallowed fire to please her husband's ghost,
Who enticed him to Elysium; Lucrece,
To purchase life unto her memory,
Noise at her funeral such as might cleave
Her fame, priced her dear heart, and died

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We have a certain faith, a faith
That can assure reward, or punishment
For deeds, we know our dwelling after death,
Which Roman souls unlawfully did seek,
And found too soon, we are prescribed those act
That makes us angels.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: She has been gossipping with the holy
Sisters, zeal, and purity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It were safer for my soul; if yourself
Would be my executioner.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I thank you lop. I am exposed
To the justice of the law, he whose rich
And his prince become his heir cannot live long;
Besides my hopes to enjoy the Duchess,
Are then quite frustrate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What said your lop.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I did not think Carintha thou hadst been
So stern of nature, t'hast a stubborn heart;
Deny my first request.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Should I kill myself.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why must we not all die, 'tis a thrifty
Conscience that persuades the soul to hasten
her departure hence to avoid future guilt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You counsel strangely, I have deserved more
Kindness from your tongue.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: If thou suspectest thou hast not fortitude
Enough, t'attempt thy death by violence:
Expire with leisure: refrain from meat, till
Th' orifice of thy stomach close, and grow
Together; or when thou feedest, eat arsenic,
Die any way, so the law call not me
Thy murderer.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Heaven secure me, have you the use of all
Your senses, ye speak thus?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But if you'll choose an easier way, each morning
Fetch a tedious sigh or two, 'twill make your
Heart to cleave, I'll give you cause enough to do't.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You have a bloody mind.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Or as some country virgins do scratch mortar
From an aged wall and eat it up in
Private, so die on the green disease, but now
I think upon't that's to perplex away,
Unto the grave.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I dare not hate the thought you've tempted me,
Beyond mortal patience, o unkind
Destiny.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Do, fret, gall thy heart strings till they break,
I've the engine of a babe, any man
That had arrived at half my years, would soon
Invent a safe way to shift that trifle
From him. Hum, who shall I get to do't.
Happy fancy, 'tis mature I will
Above it straight.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I sent you a letter madam.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My lord I received it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: How did you taste it?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Excellently.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I have twenty as good as that lying by me, have I not

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: O my good lord. (Crispino

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: They shall be all at your service.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You're too much a courtier, I must chide you
Signior, I never did deserve the epithets
Your paper throws upon me.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Epithets I beseech you madam to impute
That to the fretfulness of my brain,
If any thing have slipped my pen whereby I may incur
Your ladyship's indignation I'll recant
It publicly.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I enjoin no such penance,
But 'tis an injury easily remitted,
'Tis the glory they say of lovers to hyperbolise.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Hypberbolise, what's that? I ha' not that word
Yet in my alphabet, I hope madam you
Hold a better opinion of me then to imagine
I would hyperbolise with your ladyship;
That were immodest.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Not so signior.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: By my faith madam but it is, de think
I know not what hyperbolizing is,
That were simplicity, if any thing
Within my letter may be drawn within
Construction of hyperbolizing, condemn
Not me for't, by service madam, I
Had no intention to stretch so far
To your dishonour, it shall teach me wit
To write my letters hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: A hair in your honour's lock is disordered,
'Tis rectified,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Signior,
You do me much too much satisfaction,
Your error being a small one.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: 'Tis your favour,
Yet when I commit a peccadillo
Against your brightness, I deserve to be
Extinguished your presence for't, I did love
You madam, as I remember when I was an infant,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Dep.
sp.l: We are infants you will grant
When we cannot speak, and I loved full eight months
And a half ere I had power to tell you on't
I'm certain.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I was not worth so much.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Nay for that madam
I'll show myself deserving, were you worthy
'Twere the less act of mine to love you,
That were a poor thing, I do not stand on worth.
Madam I would not have you think so ignobly of me,
That I affect you for your worth, I'd rather
Upon my honour have you in your smock,
Than all the ladies in the world stark naked.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Now your language is course.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: You shall pardon me for that.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Your lordship's feather waves to much towards the
'Tis now in true point. (East,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: My love is pure and like the sun transparent.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Now you compliment, I know
You're excellent at it.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Troth not I lady,
I cannot compliment, I do but
Refulgent your beauty, whose mellifluous voice
Pierces the ear — faith madam credit me
I ne'er could compliment in my life: most fair,
Whom young Apollo courted for her hair.
There are poetical furies in the city,
But I converse not with 'em.
Were ever cheeks of roses, locks of amber
Ordained to be imprisoned in a chamber,
Laura I do but piddle, a pretender,
I know not how to compliment.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You now do.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Alas not I, I cannot make verses neither;
Thy dainty seal of virgin wax,
That nothing but impression lacks.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Your lordship's cloak discovers not sufficiently the riches of the inside.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: An excellent poet.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I'll tell you madam a strange thing, you see
These trifles; before I was in love, I could
Not ha' made an acrostic in a day,
Sometimes two.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Now you can make chronograms.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I think I can, and anagrams for a need.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Signior you are wonderful improved,
Love has inspired you richly. I perceive
Cupid is a mute too.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: O now I cannot sleep for the multitude,
Of verses that are capering in my skull.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I wonder you are not mad.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: A hair in your honour's lock is disordered.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: But I've a gift to help it, I allow
Myself set times to vent 'em, they would blow
Me up else.

sp.speaker: Lau,
sp.l: As how pray.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Why thus ith' morning
When I have said my prayers in verse, which fall
From me, and I ne'er think on 'em, next my heart
I scribble out an ode, after my breakfast
I fall upon a satire, when I've railed
Myself into a fresh stomach, I dine,
Which done, because it is not good to study
Upon repletion or full stomach, you
Understand me; for a matter of two hours
I dream as it comports with our Italian
To sleep, than I say, I dream familiarly
An heroic poem.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Dream.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Madam while you live,
Your dreaming poets are the best, and have
Distilled raptures, spirits that converse with 'em,
And teach 'em what to write; this I set down
Before I eat again, after I walk
Upon the strength of supper into th' park,
and ruminate an elegy at return,
I do discourse of epigrams, and an epitaph
Upon some one or other of my kindred.
I ha' made a rare one on my uncle, and
He would die shortly to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: If you so methodize your study signior
I shall but sin against your muse, 'tis now
Your hour by course, for your heroic poem:
'Twere best you sleep my lord, I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Nay madam, 'tis not every day I study
So hard, on some I whet my muse

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Your lordship's weapon hangs to much a fore.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Thou hast my bosom, treasure up my secrets
Faithfully, and deserve I should be thine;
Giotto, the first opportunity
Commends thee to the Duchess, then's the time,
To show thy gratitude, if she still look on me
With lucky eyes.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord you've made
Yourself the creditor of what I am;
If I return you not the interest
Of all my service, I should justly forfeit
To be unmade again.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Sweet Laura, world confounding beauty.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Again hyperbolising, than you lordship
Must pardon me.

sp.speaker: De,
sp.l: What's the signification of this word? hum.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I have heard some say, to hyperbolise
Is to lie, and it may be she would not have
Your lordship lie with her.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Signior de patri, what part of your discourse
Concerned my death, I heard with madam Laura
You name your uncle's dying.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: 'Twas with grief then,
I had no cause to name you else my lord.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Apply yourself nephew to this gentleman,
and make him precious to you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I shall study his honour's service.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Giotto.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: You are a scholar.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I have lost time in Padua.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I'll tell you a jest a gentleman ith' court
Writing a letter to his mistress could not
Contain himself from hyperbolising with her.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Is your lordship serious?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: True upon my honour, what a gull 'twas
To make himself ridiculous, I laughed at him,
Than he asked me what that word meant, Giotto
What do you think on't?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I my lord,
Your honour needs no comment to inform you,
Much less my translation.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Yes I know't, but what says your dictionary.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your lordship shall pardon me, for that hyperbolising

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: It is some bawdy word, he is so modest,
Wherein did I hyperbolise with her ladyship:
My lord Volterre.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Signior de Pazzi comesta.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I am transported to see your lordship well.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Io soy il uvestra servadore.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: What's this?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Between Goth and Vandal, Spanish.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: And Giotto were not here now, I would ask him
What were hyperbolising by your lordship's favour.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Women are taken with the presence of
A man, the garb, and ornaments of state
Endear him to their senses, I would fain
Appear in glorious habit can you dance?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I were no lord else, I was a French man's scholar,
For twenty crowns a month, you may guess by that
My abilities.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: 'Tis the best fooling, and the safest for
the body, your French glide away like rivers,
Without a noise, and turning with meanders,
Out move ye, your lofty tricks, are tude,
And do to much examine.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: May we not rise,
I ha' known good dancers rise at court, what say you to
A cross caper.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Ride the cannon, and you ha'
No care to preserve your bonds, but I forget,
Adios signior, I must attend the Duchess.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Do not hyperbolise with her my lord.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Pardonate signior mio.

sp.speaker: De,
sp.l: 'Tis so, 'tis bawdy, that shrug tells me so, Giotto.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your honour's servant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Were you never a courtier before.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I only hitherto have spent my eyesight.
In observation, now I grow proud to write
Myself dependant.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Signior Comachio my uncle, lends you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But I'm not to learn
To adore the rising sun, I look on him
As in his West, but I've ambition
To merit your grace.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I see than thou wot be a courtier.
sp.stage: Enter Duchess, Comachio, Contarini, Volterre, Laura.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Comachio, show me your nephew!
You're welcome to court my lord.
sp.stage: De Pazzi kneels, kisses her hand,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: It is your highness' pleasure I should presume so,
And I am confident I may.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He has not only profited in growth
Of person, but in's judgement too: talks well,
Our court wants such Comachio, your nephew's
Contemplation ends here. Padua must
Lose him, he shall be our servant.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: She jeers him, and I gain no credit by 't.
Keep your tongue quiet, cease your abortive
Language, or I'll cut your throat.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: This is the trick of all courtiers,
They would engross princes e'en to
Themselves, I must not speak to her.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: This is the gentleman, your grace was pleased
T'accept from my commends.
sp.stage: Leads Giotto to her, who kisses her har.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You are a Florentine.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I am proud to own my country.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We have heard so much of your demerits,
That 'twere injustice not to cherish you,
Be confident, to gain our best favour.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I've often prayed for this blessed hour, and thought
I did not sin in my ambition.
It is a virtue to covet honour
From your excellence: which I shall ever
Study to deserve.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Laura begin your trial.
sp.stage: Laura whispers with Giotto Orseollo runs in and kneels.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This is a rude kind of duty, speak your
Intention.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Twice have I kneeled to gain your kindness in
My suit, now grant it, or I'll turn traitor.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Make your suit known.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I have been bred in rugged wars,
A woman's government is soft and fit
For babes to bow to, dismiss straight your court.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Orseollo, did not your offence breed mirth,
You should perceive't more difficult to find
A pardon fort.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Send me straight to sea, if but t'incounter
A fleet of fiends rigged by witches, or with
A colony to settle a plantation
In the deserts of Barbary, I'll choose
Any employment rather than to hear a
Lady utter perfumed breath, or see her
Advance in her masculine garb, in her
New mimic posture.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Leave us ▪ but so, that in an hour's space
We may command your presence here, to move
Our laughter, when leisure will permit it,
Or you shall never live to wear grey hairs.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I'll conspire with a constable, that commits
Justice in's sleep, ere I'll want treachery
To revenge this constraint of service.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Your grace will beget charity in
Other ladies, if you pardon this his
Bold behaviour, for he offends all women.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How Comachio.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Does not your excellence know, he is called
The woman hater.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Deserves he that epithet?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I'll show your highness the real cause, why
He hates all women; he was ever bred
In the camp, where there are no females, but
Sutler's wives: fit drudges, to make fierce
Ith' devils kitchen, whose very looks
Disparage the complexion of all their sex;
He ne'er conversed with an Italian
Bona roba, a plump lady, that fills
Her grown, or with a French brunette,
A Spanish muser umbrada, or a
German yefrow, the Dutch. —

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Or with a Welsh —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Parrot! will ye be prating?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: What should a man do with's tongue, an ye
Won't let him talk.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My lord Volterre, is a copious linguist.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I still desire to be enabled for
Your grace's service.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Are all the sluices stopped, that we may see
Your cormorants dive for their prey?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: We only want your highness' presence there,
And the sport begins.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Comachio —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior? these are your cormorants, you still
provide the Duchess new game, and pleasure:
She did you public grace, this morning too
Before the French leiger; but you ha' travailed sir.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: My lord, the French conceive things with justice
I'm but an isorit du moude, and as
The Spaniard says, altera, estrabajo
Del hombre, but I've observed her grace names
Contarini often, looks on you with
A smooth brow.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: On me my lord?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Lead forward to the river.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My hopes do still increase, fate smiles on me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Signior de patri, be you near us.
sp.stage: Exit. Volt. Dep. Contar. Com. Dutch.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You've heard her graces will, this is the first
Employment. She knows you Florentines
Insinuate with great subtlety in
Humane natures.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: She shall receive each man in's just character,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sir I congratulate your new fortune,
You'll find her excellence a noble mistress.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You are a gentle lady, and add much
Credit to her court.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: We shall lose the sport unless we hasten
To the river.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You have use of my attendance, and I am
Happy in't.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You now shall stay at court Carintha, see
Her very lips look black. Saturn's issue.
Were not so dull and sullen.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Madam sh'as great motives unto sadness
Which I've been earnest with her to reveal,
but she conceals 'em as the usurer doth
His treasure: striving to beguile noise,
And lessen the number of his bags with
His report.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Lady, too soon you will deprive the world
Of your dear presence, if thus early you
Consume your hours in pensive thoughts!

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Carintha, have I not power to increase
Your grief; if you conceal the cause of it
From me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am not sad, my faculties preserve
Their wonted harmony: your excellence
Will not enforce me to belie my passion.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: There's my lord Volterre, is't your grace's
Pleasure to retire till we have ended
Our discovery.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Is he come? Carintha, follow me!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: She gave the game high applause, and begged two
Of my cormorants: I must invent new
Sports to delight her fancy.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The day afford your lop much profit.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: If your lop be in good health, ye owe
Some thanks unto my prayers.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Laura, the Duchess great favourite
Giotto, is eminent in court too.
If these afford me such respect I've cause
To think my stars faithful? Madam I would
Kiss your left hand —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I beseech your lip enforce me not
To be unmannerly you are now above
My conversation.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: How bright Laura. Signior Giotto.
Pray clear this mystery.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord, be more particular, for my
Own part I know my distance, but you greet
Your fortunes with too much humility,
you want state to converse with me.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I me all wonder and amazement signior,
Pray give your meaning more perspicuous
Utterance.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Will you forget to be reserved, know your
Station, you make me bold against my own
Desire.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I implore your lordship leave I may be
Covered, 'twould much assist my health.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Why, dost keep thy head bore in reverence
To me? Madam, shall I entreat? —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to command, in my
Duty to obey.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Your duty —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It seems he hath not yet; how much the
Duchess favours him — Volterre listens.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I conjecture so for e's differs much
From that which he must practise when he's Duke

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I hear ye —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: How my lord?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Laura, faith be public! Giotto, why
Dost thou conceal the means to make thee
Happy? —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord I know little, only those that
Wait near the Duchess, hear her often praise
Your nimble tongue, your skill in languages.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Phse questo mionto, what would you say,
There me interpret the inarticulate
Voices of birds, and beasts, that skill deserved
A fame.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your lordship might then (With great ease) been
Interpreter to the bvilders of Babel.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Something I've heard her grace speak too, in praise
Of your French gesture, your sublime frisk, and
Odd conveyance of your body.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Tis when your lordship wreathes your hams in thus.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Ta da rum, ta da rum, te re re, ra da rum.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: These are the postures that inchant your sex.
Lady —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I cannot blame the Duchess to be fond.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But does not your lop grow weary with
Continuance of this motion?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: It is my vulgar exercise ta da rum, ta da rum.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Enough, enough, my good lord, sure your swim
Within your doublet.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Giotto, now I am fit for a race,
Never tired. It has been thought by some (Skilled
In th' ability of my person) that
I'm mortal.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Indeed sir 'tis not fit you should expect
Much in heaven, having such joy on earth.
You are more than happy, this lady knows it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Dost i'faith Laura —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sir, I hope when you shall sit invested
With royal ornaments, you'll not disdain
Laura for your humble servant.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And Giotto knows that your religion
Will not permit you slight industry.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I took part of my breeding ith' French court ▪
And there I learned to be familiar
With my nobles.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Did not I say he would govern gently,
Now can't my tongue be quiet, I must tell him all.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Nay madam —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Giotto, dost concern you to hinder
This her kindness? speak dear lady.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My lord I affect truth and brevity,
I am commanded by her grace to make
Your visits private to her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Ha, forward dear Laura.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why sir, it is her highness' will that you
Conceal these visits.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And let no encouragement neither from
Her eyes nor speech embolden ye to think
Unlawful, her favours you must take
with silent observation.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Here comes my lord Comachio. Away signior
He must not see you.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Yo soy mug juoderose.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My noble patron. —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I greet thee as my best genius, thou'rt now
Mixed ith' number with such as wear my title,
Thou climbest apace, yet safely too; they strive
At court, who first shall be the flatterer:
What female wast that left thee now? I saw
Part of her gown.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The lady Laura.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Thou art most happy, skilful in thy choice
Of conversation: why she governs
Her highness' heart. Didst question her
About my business?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I know all, she cannot hide a single
Thought from me.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Thou'rt strangely powerful o'er ladies,
But what said she? have I no rival in
The Duchess love.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Sir, she owns none but you, with a public
Confidence, only there is own impediment.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: What is't? prithee give't relation?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: A spirit not tamed by his religion
Would hazard much rather than suffer it
Endanger such a hope.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Make it no more a secret.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Could ye think she has observed your nephew
With an amorous eye.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: De pazzi, my nephew?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That's the man sir, who is so much obliged
Unto her memory.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: 'Sdeath this inclines so near miracle
'Twould tax my judgement to believe it;
Confer her love upon a fool.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Pardon me sir! I do not positively
say she loves him. I make it (For your sake)
A cautelous suspect your jealous men
Strive against danger.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I do affect thy discipline.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: This morning she desired to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: To speak with him - good our brains are near us,
Ere thou admitst him to her presence, we'll
Furnish him with discourse, preposterous
Unto sense, and her demands; so make him
More cheap in her conception, here he comes.
Assist my prayers.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Signior uncle,

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Nephew opportunely
Signior Giotto hath taken pains
To bring us knowledge of new graces, which
Our Duchess stores up for you, I am proud
To think what honour all our blood receives
From you, the top bough of our family:
I never hoped there could be stars in heaven
So auspicious, as I behold now shining,
And pointing all their golden beams on you,
The Duchess loves you —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Not carelessly, and with that common favour,
She does divide among the courtiers,
They do but glean her scattered graces,
For you the harvest's reserved and brought
Home to your bosom.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Other with much labour.
Climb this high rock, upon whose swelling top,
The Duchess smiles are placed, yet obtain not
One to reward their sweat.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But her own hand
Reaches you up, and tempts you to enjoying
The pyramids' height, you may ascend by stairs,
And mount with ease unto that happiness,
Others adore afar off.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Does the Duchess
affect me honourably, and for marriage otherwise?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: That makes the music high, it were not else
So ravishing, you are the man marked out
To be the Duke Depazzi.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That's her desire,
She would not like a thief steal joys, but make
The pleasures lawful, nuptial holy rites,
Ushering your felicity, you must be
Her husband signior, and all we your subjects,
Obsequious to your nod, when you have breath
To raise t'unlimited height, and uncreate
Whom you would frown upon.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I see she is wise,

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: How will Comachio think his age blessed, to see
Princes born to his nephew, and with breath
Covetous to expire in prayers for them.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Kneel there great uncle,
I have an ambition
If you think not the honour over great,
To beg tuition of your second son,
Whom I should study to bring up, with such
Choice education, as shall become
The greatness of his soul and birth.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: 'Tis granted, my second son is thine, but are you sure
I am ordained to be the man you talk of;
Must I be craned up to that altitude.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord
You may be confident, Giotto dares not
Play with your greatness, and my dare was never
Yet so incertain, when I hear your name
So sweetened by your Duchess breath.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: No more, I have a strong faith, 'tis so, for my uncle
Doth practise already his observance, I
Purpose to visit our loving Duchess.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Nay you will be sent for and be courted to
That was intimated.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: But my honoured nephew
Would you admit instructions, for I see
With how much envy of the court you rise
To this high sphere of sovereignty, be prudent,
arm yourself with some excellent discourses (Thoughts.
For your first parley, you shall knit her soul to your own

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: If my abilities may do you service.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Giotto, you are furnished to read lectures
To us both of courtship, and I know my nephew
Will gratefully remember, what you add
To raise him to our wishes.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I desire to be a bankrupt of knowledge, when
My portion may enrich you.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Should you lose
Your brain signior in my service, you
Should find I would requite you.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: At his first entrance to her grace's presence
Something new and sublime, t'insinuate
How much she hath consulted with her best
Wisdom, when she elected one so meriting,
To be her husband.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: So with one argument
He magnifies her judgement, and his worth.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I like that well, if you do pen that speech
Commend me pray unreasonable, I shall study it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: That must be, to this we may guess she will
Reply, my lord, I could miss in such a troop
Of deservers to choose out the ablest.
Meaning my nephew.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I know that, who else?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Hence take you fresh occasions to extol
Yourself, and be not nice to let her know
Your active blood, and spirit to get princes,
How much the people will be bound to bless
Her race in choosing you, whose promising body
Is able to incite them to make bonfires
For Dukes unborn.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Great reason, proceed.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It will be necessary you disparage all men
That are about her, though your uncle, he
Will suffer to advance you.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Who my nephew?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Let me alone to disgrace him.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It gives you lustre principally remember
To rail against her ladies, call 'em hags,
You cannot be too bitter, this secures
Your love toth' Duchess, beats of jealousy
When you appear to love her only of
All the sex.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: It will be a good occasion to beat off
Laura, to whom I did pretend myself
A lover excellent, pray let me have all these
Directions in manuscripts, I'll not see her
Till they be rotten in my head.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Giotto, bind us both to you, this will do't,
Art cannot shape him more ridiculous,
These are rare principles. Here's Contarini.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Remove yourselves: 'tis not fit he see ye.
Signior Contarini, your minute is expired.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I crave your pardon signior, have you learned
From Laura ought that concerns my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I have cause to entreat my intelligence.
I am your pensioner, you have enriched
My stable with a Barbary Roan.
A gift I am ignorant to requite;
I must return great thanks too, from the
Lady Laura, for the wealthy carcanet
You sent her last night.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I me yet indebted to you both: signior
You are skilled in my affair: the noise still
Continue, our great Duchess will elect
A husband from her own court, I'll only
Know the man; that so I may direct my
Observance the right way, you will call this
An honest policy.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your contemplations are too humble.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You signior?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Ere I would think another worthier than
myself, to bear a sovereign title;
I would disclaim my judgement and run mad.
But there's a cross bar to your ambition,
(Heaven excuse my sorrow for it?) you are
Married, you have a wife.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you give your meaning more expression

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Has the Duchess any name within her memory,
So much as Contarinies?
Are not you he whose feature she admires?
Nay sir, it is not long since Laura heard
Her wish you were unmarried: interpret
My relation as you please;
But you know princes are reserved. What's he?
My servant signior, he has modest ears
And a quiet tongue. Dandalo, you may
Stay here, I shall use thy consent in a business.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I wait your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But did her grace wish I were unmarried?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: By no iteration that breeds noise.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Well, I allow of her graces wish.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: How my lord?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: If my marriage discontent her highness:
I wish I had no wife —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: He has a noble soul! is there no way
To avoid this trifle called a wife.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yes signior, there are ways, but —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O sir, discharge your mind, it concerns my
Prefer to be faithful.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Troth, were all impediments cleared, I think
We two should rule equally;
I'm strangely fond to those I love.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Signior you have given me cause to know it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: If I could sue out a divorce — —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I signior, but the judge grants nonē without a
Lawful cause.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: She shall commit adultery.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Giotto, that I am come to tell thee.
She's a beauteous lady, soft and buxom?
Thou shalt lie with her.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Ay, my lord?
'Twere an endearment too great for my requital.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis decreed, come, it must be so.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Signior, I shall beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I keep my mercy for another use,
Suspect no danger, you shall come disguised
When you woo her to't, which done, the Duchess
Shall help my procurement of a divorce:
Why, I knew before, her highness loved me!
I have received favours from her looks and and speech.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Does not your man listen?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: No matter, he's our confederate.
Dandalo know this gentleman's hands
And kiss 'em often.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I'm his humble creature.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I shall be glad to show you kindness.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Let's perfect our design, good signior
I have no leisure now to ruminate,
I affect action.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Madam, I ha' signified to my lord
What you commanded, but I hope your ladyship
Hath heard his disposition.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: He's not reconciled to our sex,
He has proclaimed that.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: This place breeds no ladies,
No not for civil entertainment, we
Have not a woman in the house, their pictures
Which adorn other galleries, you see
Tempt not the eye here, all his offices
Discharged by men, he says where he commands
He must not see a woman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What not strangers?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Such is his will.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: If you desire his presence and discourse,
you must be veiled here madam, his own eye
Must not be witness to what face he speaks,
I'm but his servant.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Tell him I'll expect him in that form hen
Prescribes.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: The other lady too
Must be clouded, then I'll let his lordship
Know you're prepared.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Pray do madam, I hope
Your discontent will give you leave to smile
At this, her grace found you but this employment,
With me, to beat your melancholy off,
Apply to the occasion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My gratitude will teach me to conform.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Now ladies what's your pleasures, that you summon
My appearance, I know ye ha' supple joints,
What mystery of state sends you to me?
I cannot revel in long stockings, frisk
To please your wanton eyesight; I ne'er boasted
'My ribs, or largeness of my thighs, to invite you;
I make no sonnets of your antic dressings,
Cry up your colour of your face, and swear
You're divine pieces, for I know you are not:
I will not draw heavens curse upon me, for
Flattering into pride; say that the lilies,
Are pale, for envy of your white, and the roses
Blush, to see better in your cheeks, your hair
Beams, rather drawn up to a net, might catch
Jove when he played the eagle; that your breasts
Raise up themselves like two fair mountainers
Ith' pleasant vale of temptation, I hate this
I will not dam myself to make you proud,
Do not, I know your faces?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ours, we are not ashamed to show 'em.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Do not unveil.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Good madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Will you not see what you condemn?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I'm gone, if you attempt to let me seem
A piece of any countenance; while I thus
Look on ye, I can help myself t'imagine
Ye are some other creatures.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Troth my lord, for pity to yourself
End your invectives;
Madam I told you of this mirth.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Can he be serious?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Wrack me not with your stay,
What's the design hath brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: This signior; 'tis the Duchess pleasure
You make sudden repair to court.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: That's our embassy.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I am no court physician, I but vex
Your female constitutions, you know
All my receipts are bitter, and her excellence
Hath plenty of those, she gives a pension to
Can flatter; why does she send for me am so
Unwelcome?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My lord, her grace employs
Not me to any so unhappy:
And though you have not lived so near the favour,
Ith' eye of the court, which your own humour too
May have been the cause, I have no honour, if
You find yourself unwelcome,

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: 'Tis a mystery.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I could instruct you further with a secret,
Your soul would dance to know, but I confess
'Tis more than my commission:

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Is there in nature any happiness for men?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And from a woman: you will come my lord?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Stay, from a woman, ha? the Duchess —
Heard a noise she would choose a lover from
Her own court, can it be that? death I haven
Been boundless in my railing. I begin
To curse myself fort.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Be all silence,
thou hast a knowledge will be dangerous
To any hope, perhaps, I could be pleased
To see the tip of your nose lady,
Or the mole upon your chin.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You will have cause to bless the occasion
Of this day's message.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I could see your cheek,
Nay half your face for tother syllable.
Lady you can say more,

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I dare not signior, already we have exceeded.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I know such creatures cannot mock, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Have you not heard her grace's resolution,
Touching a husband?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: You are o'er dark still, enrich me,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I hope your honour will remember this poor service when 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: What? one letter of your meaning.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My lord the Duchess loves you.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Come madam, I shall say you will wait.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Shall I not see the faces,
To which I owe my blessedness.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: No words of those loose creatures in your custody,
Seal up the doors, still the air lest that
Creep out too soon, and kill my growing fate.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Was not Orseollo's humour, recreation
To thee Carintha?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I spent all my thoughts
In wonder madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He began to soften —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We tamed his tiger violence, not magic
Could force him like the charm you sent.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Giotto? What speaks your haste?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Comachio madam, and signior Depazzi.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Usher 'em in.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Something in such a plenty may delight
Your dulled fancy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Laura, remove yourself,
Do not eclipse the splendour of that sun.
My eagle's eye must gaze at. Uncle know
Your distance.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Signior Depazzi.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Giotto, my hand again, be proud, now madam
I address myself to you, wonderful Princess,
Not so much for your beauty as your wisdom,
Your carnal wisdom.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Wherein signior.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Right you answer, right it is my cue:
Your carnal wisdom madam, you proclaim
In choosing out a husband, and that man
Whose memory your subjects shall have cause
To curse, is I.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To curse?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Perfect still, have cause to curse,
You did no sooner choose him, which of all
Your fair lords, though you look a squint upon
My merit, could your eye pick out more able?
Heroic, complete, tempting? I am fleshed,
Nothing shall put me out.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Observe.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Your grace says right, I do acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You are too hasty, her grace says nothing.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Did your grace say nothing? speak it again,
I know you meant to say something to th' purpose.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What purpose signior?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Now she has put me quite out.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Then rail upon your uncle.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Look on him madam, there he stands, you may
Perhaps imagine him for his grey beard
And a starched face, that he is wise a statist:
I'll bring ye a justice, that's but newly packed
Into commission, oth' peace, shall make
An ass on him.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Nephew, this will make you odious.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: A very gull in mystery of state,
A most egregious — in comparison
Of one that I could name, but he may serve
To fright the pages, muster the black guard,
Or keep the door at masks, his face will do
More than a hundred others; yet now I think on't,
Your grace shall magnify your favour to me,
And let me beg him.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I hope your grace will pardon him, these fits
Are ever at full moon.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Beg your uncle signior?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Yes I would furnish him with an
Hourglass and a scythe;
And sell him to the masons for the picture
Of time, madam, would he not show well?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This is witty, what detractor
Gave out signior Comachio, your nephew
Had no rich brain, Carintha, do you nold him
Laura, Comachio, ha?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Giotto, she has put me out again,

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Then rail upon her ladies,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Hum, when I contemplate on your highness' face
I hate all others.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Can your excellence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Why, is mine so bad?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, speak your part right,
Oblivion is my cue. I do remember.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Madam Carintha, speak to her grace.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Has madam Laura such I lip or eye?
I do confess she has a nose, but I
Pass over it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: He makes a bridge of that,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Her cheeks, —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Nephew — madam I humbly pray I may remove
This rudeness, 'tis a discord must needs grate
Your soft ear,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Uncle you are out now, her cheeks.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Well signior, what of my cheeks.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Why your cheeks are, as they are, death, I ha' forgotten.
This 'tis when you won't come t'rehearsall.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My cheeks are
Such as creation framed 'em, and the colour
Is nature's gift.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: It had need be gift, I know none so prodigal
To be at charge to buy 'em, yet you thought
I was in love w'ye, I confess I did
Once cherish an opinion you were something
About a Gipsy, and might serve in Lent
When flesh was rare, but you must take into
Your thoughts, I meant not honestly, you see
For whom fate hath reserved me, be as patient
As such a loss will suffer you, do not mar
Your face, cause I condemn it, it may serve
Some hungry signior, or some city heir
That would be dabbled in nobility,
And pay for his cornuting.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He is most witty Carintha.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Giotto, she is taken with this imprudence,
What dulness hangs upon her soul? some fatal
Apoplexy seize him, that which we
Plotted to make him hateful does inchant her.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Madam, you see I have a body, ponderous
And full of marrow, I'll not get an heir
Less hopeful than myself, my first son shall be
An emperor born, may I do things to purpose
When I am in once.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Will not this startle her?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sure madam, he will put down Hercules.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Hercules, Hercules, what, a pedlar.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Pedlar, my lord you would say piddler.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: He shall be what I please, do not I know Hercules,
He got but fifty in a night, but I —
Madam your ear.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My duty to your grace, makes me forget
He is my kinsman.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Signior Depazzi,
We have leisure to hear you finish your discourse
With Laura and Carintha.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: He's courted to her privacy, her soul is
In a deep lethargy.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Ha?
What was intended to destroy his hope,
Hath raised him to assurance, she applauds
That which to all understanding but her own,
Appears prodigious, did you suspect
She would hear this prate?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: He had committed sin enough to have had
His lips sowed up eternally, death, I could
Grow into death with wonder.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: She checked you for interrupting.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: A fury revels in my brain, she's mad,
And so am I, but —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What for prevention,
If she have such a poverty in her reason,
Ith' humour she may marry him, and then
Beside the mighty fortune lost, you groan
Under his tyranny.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: In his blood I'll bathe
My fears, a ship launched forth with all her wings,
Be calmed thus.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I'll dig the remora
That hangs upon the bark, this fool would not
Be missed among the living, rather than —

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Thou'rt my genius sacred director
To my bliss.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I ha' so much suffering
In your ungentle stars, that I would purchase
Their better influence with my danger.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: How I feel my heart incorporate with thine,
What do I owe to heaven for sending me
Thy friendship, say, shall this thing be removed,
Giotto, that so ruins me.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Shall: there is
A most severe necessity, you must not
Be conscionable now; and charity
Unto yourself, will drown the sin:
Retort disgrace t'your hate.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I shall extend my favour, where I see
Merit invite, perhaps commend you to
Some other lord; uncle, you shall continue
Your place; Giotto find out a monopoly,
It shall be signed.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I congratulate your high fortune,
I knew 'twould take.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Here's a pretty front,
Signior Orseollo, stay till I am valid. —

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Nay, good madam, I can endure to see
Your face, without danger to my eyes — signior
Giotto, I joy in your great fortunes.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: They shall enable me to do you service.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: My lord, you cherish my instructions,
You're come earlier than your hour.

sp.speaker: Ors
sp.l: I'd fain know my destiny; madam I'm rough.
The wars have spoiled my courtship; I cannot
Flatter kindness from you; but I affect
Gratitude. What news lady, hah? has there
Been no mention of my name or person
Since I received your last intelligence?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I know nothing but what I am enjoined
To make a secret.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: How dear lady.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Giotto, shall I tell him that?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Not for both the Indies.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: But she shall Giotto, she and we be kind, —
Madam, — we three will share in all achievements.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I cannot hide it from him.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Are you weary of your life lady?
My hopes are finished.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: The Duchess has commanded him to get
Your picture for her.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Who'd trust a secret in a woman's breast?
My lord, as you esteem our loves useful
Let no ear enjoy this but your own.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I will forget I heard it; ay, I me a soldier
Signior, and shall deserve your faith. Sancho!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: My lord!

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: There's a famous painter sojourns here
In Mantua, a german!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Shadan wierex.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: The same, you are to seek him out, I have
Use for him.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Already you begin to make it public.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Do not suspect my servant's silence, I
Trust him with a secret of weightier
Consequence than this, my creature! hunk ▪

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Your hopes increase signior.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, Giotto, thine too:
We'll govern like the triumveri —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But sir, there is one obstacle —

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I'll lose a thumb to have it cleared.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Heart, let me but know't?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You've heretofore appeared so boisterous
And sullen to that sex, that the Duchess
Partly thinks —

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: What does she think?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: You're insufficient.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: How? A metaphrase upon that word.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Sir 'twould impeach her modesty t'express
her meaning, ith' blunt dialect, however
'Twill become my tongue; there's a noise amongst
The ladies, you're insufficient: that is
Your genitals want the perfect help in
Procreation.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Horror, horror, name the author of this
Calumny.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Be not so loud signior, were it a truth
'Twould not proclaim nature, or your parents
Guilty, you are a soldier, perhaps in
A skirmish at Lepauto, some Turk
Circumcised you with his scimitar;
Or being at push a pike, you might be
Drilled below the navel, nay I ha' known
The breath of a bullet snatch a remnant
Of loose flesh.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: 'Sdeath insufficient! you shall know a secret
Which I have feared, even ith' keeping of my own heart.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Twill trouble me to know a thing, so full
Of danger.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: 'Tis only dangerous to me, but sir,
It must out, for I'll stifle now this damned
Aspersion. It reveals the cause, why I
Was still a satire against women.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Ay, that I would fain know.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Know what lady? we are in a discourse, merely,
Concerns us two, walk aside, she must not hear't.
Sancho, I now release off the oath,
Which did oblige your secrecy about
My continence, nay good madam, troth we
Desire to be particular.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Hereafter I shall grow reserved too.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: A personal secret, as I'm a soldier.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You shall believe him lady for my sake.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: How many whores hast thou in keeping for my use?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.l: Some ten my lord!

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You pass my belief.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Alas, I'm insufficient! A mere eunuch, I.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: But what urged your invectives 'gainst the sex,
Since you thus cherish them in private!

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: The Duchess has a chaste court: 'twas safety
To disguise m'incontinence, lest she should
Punish it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You're not so ravenous (My lord) but when
Your friend desires a taste, he may be furnished, hah?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: You shall visit my seraglio, and chose your whore.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: May I presume —

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: That's the medicinal pimp; who prescribes
Plasters for my belly.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You maintain him in a gaudy outside.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: His sins maintain him; those of his function.
Grow mighty now adays.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Lady you shall share in our secret,

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Are you mad signior?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord you are to modest: there's no error
So readily excused by ladies as this
O'th blood. Fame has abused our noble friend:
Not Hercules was more enabled for
Increase; then he.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Indeed signior?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Indeed? why madam, do you doubt that I
Bely him, I'm sure he keeps ten whores.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: 'Slight, you are treacherous.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: She cries indeed, as if she did suspect
You can proffer like a goat, and perform
Like an elephant.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: This was you that railed against women.
Fie my lord.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Troth madam, my constitution is to blame.
But a young sinner deserves mercy.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your lustiness redress you more hopeful
To the state. Give me a prince from whose loins
We may expect issue.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Howsoever I would not have the Duchess know
Of this; till I am more endear unto
Her heart.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Does not her happiness, and mine depend
Upon your fate?
My lord, be confident of my silence.
Her grace is now in the privy garden.
Walk you thither, and receive those favours,
Her looks administer: without reply
Of gratitude, she would not have it known
She loves you.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Enough I shall be politic.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Was there ever such a wanton hypocrite?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: He neighs like a horse. I am not cozened
In him, I still thought he was a lecher.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior Giotto.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My good lord? —

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: 'Tis my chief blessing to see your lordship
In good health —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I thank you noble lady.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I'll go pray to have it still continued.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What means this great observance, 'tis beyond
My merit. Dost not admire her grace's
Favourite should use me thus?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: These female courtiers ha' the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What signior?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Tis safe idolatry to bow unto
The rising son, she sees your fortune smile,
And therefore flatters ye.
Heaven knows, I near
Shall gain by courtship, I
Though all the heralds
Called thee Duke, I'll not kiss your hand
Unless 'twere clean.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thou hast heard some news.
Declare, come, declare,
And prosper.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord, I first should chide your tardiness
In action. First now I saw your wife at court,
attending on the Duchess: only she
Defeats your hope; yet her removal from
Your bed is not designed.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have sent her to my house, provided you
A rare disguise which you shall wear, and woo
Her body to the dark deed, my man shall
Witness her adultery; and I'll sue out
A divorce; whilst you remain safe from law,
Because not known to her.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why this I like, it tastes of sublime wit.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I will be active in my reign, in large
My duchy. Genon is proud, it shall
Grow humble I have a long arm, 'twill reach
Florence. Or if I chance to lay my hand on Parma
I shall gripe it till my fist ache, ere I
For my tenure.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Orseollo.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Your greeting's too familiar!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: From whence this pride, I'll anger him.
My lord, though I am grown above the use
Of poetry, there still remains in my
Remembrance a sonnet, made in praise of
Women; which if you'll please to hear —

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: He had a bold muse, that durst undertake
So high an argument, sure a woman
Was the object, struck old Homer blind;
And for his eyes left him a muse. I've lost
My business.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He was not wont to speak so well of women.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: No humorist is constant to dislike,
Or commendation.
Nay lead the way my lord:
I'm part of your attendance.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Signior my affairs hither require haste,
The Duchess (On some sudden cause) hath sent for me.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I believe 'tis to take's advise about
a masine for my wedding, he's excellent
At revels. On my good lord. —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: You come lately from her, and I would know,
How you approve her present looks. 'tis the art
Of foreign courtiers to visit princes,
In lucky minutes; when their gesture shows
'Em pleasant. How looks her grace today: is,
She not physical, but high and jocund?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: You may without danger of your fortune
Choose this minute for conference with her grace.
Signior th'as cause to clear her looks; her thoughts
Grow easy to her, she had found out the man;
The man, that must: more might be said: but then
More must be spoke —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: 'Slight; why this to me; how comes he to know
That I am he, her highness aims at? True
The man is known: nor is his worth concealed.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Worth signior! — none but Laura gave him
Notice, I'm the man, I near spoke of it
Myself. My lord, the man may with safety
Boast, he is the best deserver in the court. hum.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Your lordship does him too much right, 'tis certain,
He has been told that I am he.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: He hath a glorious feature too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Nay good signior, comely; but not glorious.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: How not glorious, speak that again.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: This is a pretty kind of flattery,
He will not suffer me to abuse myself.
I'll admit he charms the ladies? or so —

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: That's I; for I charm the ladies. He knows
I shall be Duke, it cannot be concealed.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: The man has travailed too.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Never I. But it seems the Duchess gives
It out so: the more to honour her choice
Signior; I must do you justice ▪ the court
Speaks you most accurate, ith' Spanish garb.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: The Spaniards (Signior) reserves all passion,
To express his feeling in accurances
of state, when in discourse; his toothpick still
Is his parenthesis: which he doth manage
Subtly thus — par les santos sennor —
Lo conosco portierto — porque es
Trabaso (Conlicenzia diuvestra alteza)
Hablas muchas palabeas —
No puedo en veridad —

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: But why those things signior?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: This elevation oth' shoulders is a
Politic gesture, declares a meaning hidden;
Which you may find out if you can: and is
Often used in trivial circumstances.
I question this your man — —

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Your lordship must speak my mother's tongue then.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Is don Diego within?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Stay slave, we'll be as politic as he —
Which don Diego do you mean? he that played
The sloven in the great church. The English
Have a proverb on him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Why not he of Valder, or any other Diego?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Be not enraged (My lord) those grave shrugs appear
Unmannerly, and would before ladies,
Engender a suspect of vermin.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Then I'll prefer (Sir) the French to your
Dislike or praise: whom though a surly don,
Calls an impertinent people; giddy
Trifles? yet in my esteem they merit
Highly. They are active even in discourse
Let us begin cheerly, no matter
On what slight or trivial subject; be it
On that single melancholy hair upon
Your chin. Rise and fall by my example.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I am prepared.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Monsieur, sil adirent que eat cheveil la sera brusle; que farions nous
Avec vostre menton: poucce que le roy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Monsieur be not troubled! banish your fear,
for I'll toss th' Antarctic pole
With like ease as Hercules could a bulrush.
Make it a secret.

sp.speaker: Vol.
