sp.l: O vy da ', je slay bien que la volente, doit esere est emet pour facit: mais quond
Je vous donneray an cheque naude prenez lamanie, que celus, que tombe
Gaigneray un pas; pour reu, que ce veleve —

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Troth, I know not, may be it was a mistake in Plato, for those pins and feathers which you talk of, are useful unto ladies. Besides 'tis well known, the man ith' moon will not permit excuse in business of this kind: 'tis dangerous to law, and reason.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Je ne le croy pas, cesee un chanson dumonde.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: So I was told by one that knows the King's heart? he came hither to cheapen ginger bread, for the mogul's daughter.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Est i' possibile? Il in a aucun chose ci dificile, mais je le prenderay tant tose.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Dost i'faith, know then all the lions in Barbary shall not contrary me in this way.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: How do you like it signior?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: T'as put me into a heat, and French heats aren not
Very wholesome. But I've heard how nimbly
You dispose your person in a French curvet!

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: I know your mind; but my body is now prepared
For a high visit. My joints moves by screws,
I'm so starched together; a dance would
Loosen me, and make me fall in rumples.
Your man is well built for such a motion,
Mark 'tis only thus — and thus —

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I ha' seen your lordship do it ta da rum, ta da rum.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Good, very good, signior Depazzi you owe
Heaven much thanks, for lending you this servant;
I ha' not seen a gentleman in all France
Move with so much regard, and vigour.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Your lordship is my pattern.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: M'affaires call me to court, serviteur tres humble.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Is't possible? This lord must rise when I am Duke:
I'll prefer none but such as can speak French and dance;
Crispino, prepare my bath, I'll distil and grow amorous.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My lord 'twill become me to receive
Whom you give up so noble, I should sin
Against obedience; you are most welcome signior.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My best Carintha.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Madam you encourage me
To serve your goodness, my lord you undo me,
With too much honour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Signior, if your eye take delight in prospect
There's a room will feed it richly,
Show him Carintha, some
Affairs call me to court. Cherish him

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: With my best care, please you walk.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: So Dandalo, be faithful to your trust, no interruption,
Giotto prosper in thy sin, thy deed
Will make me happy, though my honour bleed.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You're very jocund on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thank your love for't, that provided
Such a cure for melancholy;
To myself I seem not to go but dance,
When shall we have a mask
My lord?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You'd be revelling again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am all for sport, your honour is much bound
To the gentleman your friend, trust me my lord
He is a rare physician.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's well skilled in women's pulses.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: There's no fear my lord,
But he'll recover me, I do like him infinitely
For my body, the best in Padua.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Good, good he gave you gentle physic,
But you hope 'twill work.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No Esculapius
Could ha' behaved him more judicially
Did our court ladies know his skill
They would be all his patients, and be sick a purpose.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You hold him then sufficient.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He has a way
So easy to do good upon's.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Upon ye ith' name of lust, you see
I had a care.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: 'Twas more compassion, and I am bound
To acknowledge it, I was all heaviness;
A thousand plummets hung upon my heart,
'Tis by your means I am made light.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I think so, very light, ha, is she not quick already,
She moves so nimbly, Giotto has don't,
I have it here, I feel it spread, hark you:
You're a whore.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Does your lordship love bastard next your heart,
Though some hold wine unwholesome, it may thaw
Your congealed blood; o the difference of constitutions.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Hey, she jeers me, how now?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: My lord, her grace hath sent a strict command
You wait tonight at court.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: The messenger seemed full of haste, he only
Took time to say her highness had resolved,
This night, to clear all doubts, and from her court
Make happy one, with title of a Duke.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Be dumb, thou bringst destruction tonight ,
Pray you may be mistaken, I am undone else.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: It is my unhappiness then my lord, to bring unwelcome truth.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Tonight , why 'tis impossible
To sue out a divorce, I'm lost, my plots
Rebound and strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My lord, you seem
Troubled, does your head ache, I'll into th' garden
And gather a few simples.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Madam a word w'e,
You magnified but now a courtesy
I did you, you were ever grateful, I
Know't, you shall not do the benefit
If you will yet kill yourself.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's a small matter.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I know 'tis, considering thou'rt stained,
Lost in thine honour, held but a disease
That grows upon thy sex, a tumour; prithee
Lance thyself 'tis soon done.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: That's a poor favour,
Well, I'll think on't tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Con:
sp.l: 'T must be done tonight , and early to, for else 'twill
Do me no pleasure dear Carintha, make thy memory
Religious.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am thinking where the sign is,
Ha, 'tis in capricornus, I'll go let
Myself blood ith' knees, and die praying,
That your lordship may recover your wits again.

sp.speaker: Con,
sp.l: A fury lend me curses, make me all
An execration, I ha' plotted fairly,
And made myself a fine rediculus thing
To no purpose, I am deep in shame, I must on
Giotto, have a nimble brain; you must sink too
Or boy me up again.
sp.stage: Enter Depazzi, Crispino, curling his hair.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Make no words Crispino, for the Duchess
Would not have it published that she means to choose me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Did she promise you?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Not by word of mouth, but I know her meaning,
As well as I were in her, I must be Duke man.
'Tis certain, everybody knows it, but say nothing
Lest it break out, hast done.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: A little with this lock, and I'll adorn your lordship
With a powder; I hope your honour will
Not forget Crispino's faithful service when you are Duke.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Why I am Duke already,
But for the ceremony, my reign's begun, Depazzi the first.
But that I'll not show myself unto my people,
Because the Duchess did entreat me, let me
See what place thou'rt fit for: o I have it,
Thou shalt be judge.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: A judge my lord

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: A judge my lord, at least, thou canst discharge it,
'Tis nothing to sit upon life and death, 'tis not
Required you should speak much, thy trade has half
Prepared thee, thou canst pole the commons, I'm sure,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: And cut off capital offenders.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Very good be it so, be a judge.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Where my good lord?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Why thou shalt be a judge in potentia.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I humbly thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: O my true friend, I have no happiness
But thou dost make me climb to't, 'twill be thy own
Instructor, and oblige me everlastingly.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I'll soon remove your fears, I cannot doubt
You will make good your promise sir, to pardon
When you're Duke.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Pardon, reward and honour thee as my preserver,
Be not observed, I am your creature.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: My lord, I have assayed which you require privacy,
Send off Crispino,

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I ha' made him a judge.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: 'Tis very trimly done of you, I cry you mercy my very
Good lord, I humbly desire your honourable absence.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: It shall be granted.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Now signior what bring you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why some tokens for your lordship, look you.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: They're no tokens of love as I take it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Yes but they are, and you must take 'em so,
but make your choice, which best affecteth you,
For one you must accept.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: O what do you mean signior.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Not too loud, lest I choose for you, here's a ball,
Better than any ere Crispino washed
Your honour's face with 'twill scour you.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Hold, are you in earnest.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: A bullet will quickly sing my errand to you,
Will you choose.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I beseech declare your meaning signior.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: In short, I me sent to kill you, if you like
Any death better than another, briefly
Resolve and have it, nay without long study.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Every man should consider his end signior, alas!

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The Duchess loves you, and there must be order
Taken to stay your raising, say your prayers.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I ha' not the heart to say my prayers,
Ah, if I must needs, I would die
Another death, you ha' not brought me.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I would choose my gallows, ah, stay 'tis very
Short warning, and I am not half prepared:
What is this, ratsbane; alas that's to kill
Vermin, I would be loath to be sent out of
The world like a rat.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What say you to a halter?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Indeed signior I never loved swinging
In my life, and the halter is a dog's death,
I would die like a man.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: What say you to a sword?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Alas I have a sword of my own, and I had a mind to't
But my stomach will never digest it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Then this pistol.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: But that I have a weak constitution,
I have always been given to looseness,
And I doubt your pellet will put me into such a scouring.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Why, would you live then?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Alas every thing would live signior, but I should be
Sorry to enjoy a life, that stood not with your liking signior.
But if I live to be a Duke. —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Duke that's the sluice opened this torrent.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I am abused dear signior, I'll renounce it,
I'll be first a dog-killer.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: This is but air, your not to be trusted,
I ha' sworn to send you into another world,
You must not more be seen.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: I won't; do but trust me,
And as I am honourable I'll go
Into the wilderness, and live with bears;
Any whether, hide me in a well, and there be no
Water in't, I'll feed on gravel;
By this hand, this seven years, none shall know
But I am dead.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: If they should find you living.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Never, I'll endure pinching to death
Ere I'll confess it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Were I certain
You would be buried to all men's sight, but till
Tomorrow.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: See me put into the ground yourself,
So you'll not smother me, and it be seven nights
I'll feed on moles sweet signior.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: The Duchess doth purpose this night her election,
Your uncle envying your hope, must ha'
Security for non appearance; had I
A faith you'd creep into obscurity,
But for twelve hours I should have one
Sin less to answer for.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Noble signior, I'll wriggle myself into a
Worm-hole, or creep into a molehill, and live
Upon emmits eggs.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Be sure you do't than, poor sick nobility,
How thin he looks already.
sp.stage: Enter Volterre at one door, Orseollo at tother.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Signior Giotto.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Now the tide comes.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: This is the night signior, 'tinclines a pace.
Do I remain unshaken in her opinion
Have I any square still.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: O my good lord.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Signior a word,
Does this night then conclude —

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your happiness.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Be not tempted from me, I have writ
Pamphlets in praise of women, I have a volume
Of recantations.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: They are fruitless,
You are fixed already in her thoughts, away
You make your person cheap, meet, and
Be happy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Giotto.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Dear signior.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What make they flattering here, ha they all hope
To enjoy her; all, only Contarini
Could gnaw his heartstrings now to be excluded,
When he expected his fate ripe, and all his
Hopes fit for gathering.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Be high and answer your great hopes;
Meet confidence.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Shalt be my fellow Caesar in the empire.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Noble Contarini.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You've store of client's signior, I am come
To know my fortune too.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Alas my lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You'd say 'tis plain writ in my forehead, yes
In capital letters; you are known to th' secretary,
That taught my wife this text hand, but you must
Do something, sure the marriage is decreed
Tonight to rid me of Carintha, or
I'll ha' thee punished for adultery.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As horns can make a man, it is no time
For patience, hear me carefully and have
Your best brains.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Adultery? was it not by your consent,
the very sinful act yours, I but moved
By your direction, will this published
Exempt you from the law?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I'll laugh at thee
With my man's help, and oath against thee, I'll
Return thy calumny ith' face, I am
A lord, and shall out weigh thee, couldst thou give
Thy truth a body, that even men might see
As well as hear it.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: This is strange and violent ha,

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Do, harrow thy skull, I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: This is but course reward for my last office,
No remedy but killing before supper;
Did my stars owe me this? you will pardon me
When you're Duke, that's but reason.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And reward thee.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I am in, and must wade through, she goes to bed
Supperless.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O happiness, may I trust to't?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I'll put her granam to the charge of worms
To entertain her, meet, and be Duke, I'll make
Your wife immortal.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Wilt thou be speedy, for I'll tell thee Giotto,
I cannot hope this night to have all perfect.
The noise of this her sudden death, must needs
Mar this nights revelling, and protract the choice
That is expected; then a little time
Presents me capable of the mighty favour:
I have encouragement to hope for marriage
With our great Duchess, ha.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Excellent brains,
Your wife is already carrying commendations.
To your friends ith' tother world.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: O let me hug thee.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I have your pardon.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And my heart too, on, be swift in thy great work
Believe it done.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This pleasantness becomes you well Carintha,
And you show duty in it, this night we dedicate
To our own delights.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Madam, I ha' more wonder
To tell your grace, when you are pleased to hear me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You'll find our disposition meet it, but
Laura, dost thou not smile to think upon
The event, we shall be censured humorous.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: But your grace shall publish your reasons,
You will appear just.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: That ambition
Should have such fear in humane natures, but
Court hath been long sick; they are my humours
And I must physic 'em.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Treason, treason, where's the Duchess, oh madam
Never was heard of such a horrid treason.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Our guard.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Nay I discovered and prevented it
Already.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You amaze us, what's the treason, who is
The conspirator?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: My uncle, but I think most of the lords
Had their hand in't:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Be brief.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: There was a plot of treason to ha' killed.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Whom? defend us heaven.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Nay I ha' defended myself, they would a killed.
Me, that shall be Duke, because they saw
You were inclined to marry me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Is this the treason?

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: And who should be the villain think you, but
Giotto.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Giotto.

sp.speaker: De,
sp.l: I Giotto, but like an honest rascal
Upon my promise, to go hide myself
For twelve hours, he saved my life, did y'ever
Hear of such a cunning traitor, but it is
Your destiny to ha' me, you have cause
To pray heartily.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And so I have, here was a piece of treason,
But be reserved you are here safe; I'll take
My time to know and punish all; what bold
Intruders this?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: My lord, I heard your voice in fearful manner
Crying treason, are you in preservation.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: One of my loving subjects; yes Crispino:
'Tis Crispino madam, one that I ha' promised
To make a judge, he was my barber, and
Will fit the common wealth to a hair.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He must deserve that place then.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: 'Tis confirmed.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I humbly thank your excellence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Signior Depazzi, you shall be near our person,
Here's mirth more than's expected; Laura, bid
Some waiter command Giotto's presence;
Carintha, we'll retire and hear your wonder.
My lord, we'll sift the treason.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: And let the traitors be bolted madam I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Quick, set things in order. The gentlemen
That come to see this great preparation,
Must please to make room for't, so, so.
What are you sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: I am the terror of the law.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: What's that, a hangman?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: When I look lean, and frown, thou diest, I am
A judge, I say, a judge in potentia.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Have we a town called potentia, in our duchy.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: He's some foreigner, he comes to use his eyes,
Let him pass.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Cease your clamours villains: sure the devils
Are singing a catch. Give order the outward
Doors be locked. Let none approach the presence;
The lords must come hither up the back stairs,
And through the privy gallery, bear back:
More noise yet, 'twere less troublesome living
In a drum then at court, in nights of
Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: My lord Comachio's voice.
sp.stage: Enter Comachio, Orseollo, they salute with silence at the door.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: The lords are not yet met.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: I hate this overgrown thing, 'tis high time
He should intend's affairs in heaven, yet still
He hath some business upon earth,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Save you my good lord, signior Orseollo,
I hope you have an able faith.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Why do ye hope so?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: That ye may be saved too.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: The groom is witty.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Who makes that noise?
sp.stage: Within. Signior Contarini and Volterre would have entrance.
Enter Contarini, Volterre, who salute each other with silence at the door, then are saluted by Comachio, and Orseollo.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Why was Contarini warned, he has a wife,
His hope have no encouragement.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: My lord Volterre, I congratulate
Your safety, and your health signior Contarini?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Is not this Depazzi's barber?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I wish he had more manners.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: There are certain judges in the dark

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: And that's the reason justice is blind.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: And those judges shall come to light too, when
They shall think convenience proper —

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: His fingers speak his profession
sp.stage: Within. Make way there, fellows oth' guard, the passage.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: Bear back gentlemen, what do you mean,
Pray bear back?

sp.speaker: Lords,
sp.l: Music then.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Attendants.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My nephew still alive, Giotto, you
Trifle with me, I am dangerous when
My wrath is.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You mistook your nephew, I proffered him
Four or five several deaths, and could not get him
To accept of one. Come signior there's great hope,
The Duchess but pretends a care o'er him,
The more to disguise her love of you.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: This is but a weak comfort.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is't done? softly in my ear?

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: It is not done.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Hell, and damnation!

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Your wife is invisible: the sun can hardly
Find her out.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Secure thyself, my ways are hidden.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Diable prend e'te droll la! parles doucement.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Do not trust the archduke, he cozened me at
Blowpoint.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Abien, ce'te unchose'ci dificile. Jene scay que fair.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: Right, why that's the cause I lent the emperor my
Comb-case.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Ma foy loblie! mais nous le voyerous tontastine grandement esbahy.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.l: With like ease may I — hand saw, and invite the
Moon to supper.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Ha, who is the cause of this fury.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: 'Tis only a French heat, an't like your excellence.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: My lord the time is now arrived wherein
We are to gain your thanks, and strive to oblige
Posterity, your care oth' public weal,
Encouraged your continual suit to heaven,
And us, that we would make an earthy choice
Of a good husband. Even from this number,
We'll perform your wishes, envy is the sin
Of cowards: therefore no lord of high birth,
And temperate breeding will malign his destiny
Whom we shall think most worthy our esteem:
Nay, 'twould show decay of duty
Ith' greatest of our court, to think that we
Want skill to make a safe election, such
A bold thought, in one we call our subject
Would soon corrupt our nature, and make our
Justice cruel; we do expect (My lords)
No verbal satisfaction in this point;
But as we single out our choice, we'll make
A private trial of each heart, Contarini:

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: I can perceive no cause of fear from him,
he's married,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How does your wife signior?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: She has too much health madam: but had I known
Your excellences purpose, to hasten thus
Your favour towards your humble subject:
She had ere this arrived in heaven: however
If your care find your blood so violent
You are not able to delay the use
Of this my person; she shall not live long
To find your desire.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O my good lord you still increase my obligation

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis great pity custom should make princes
So reserved in wooing, had ye told me
But two days since of this meeting, I had
Cashiered my wife; a nimbler way than by
Contriving a divorce.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Then you have practised a divorce already?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Alas, no design seems difficult, that makes
Me capable of your highness' love.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: What an iron impudence rules in thy
Nature? thou seemest to boast of crimes the devil
Would in modesty conceal.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How madam?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Canst thou expect kindness from a lady,
That art so cruel to thy own: a soul
So much ith' tongue of fame, as is Carintha:
You are one oth' religious faction,
Whose care merely did reflect upon the
General good; the safety of your country,
I'll not publish thy disgrace: kneel old man?
And thank the privilege of this great day;
Thou hast thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Horrid torture, foiled in my hopes, and made
An argument for popular scorn, I fear
My own shadow, my horns are grown so ugly.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Orseollo.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: She knows him a woman hater, his fate
cannot hinder me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: How thrives your charity towards our sex,
What think you of a woman now my lord?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: A woman is the pride of nature: her
Husbands best Gaurius, made to credit
Heaven, to justify the first creation good:
She is the destiny of time, her womb
Contains the hope of our succession,
The power to add new life unto the world.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Stay signior, this is a kin to flattery,
Do you appear at this our summons, with
Hope to gain by it: you that have professed
Yourself a natural enemy to all our sex?

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Madam I recanted that heresy,
Giotto is my witness: there are creatures —

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: He'll tell me all I need not tempt it from him,
Bold monsieur, I've heard of your goat tricks
Of your seraglio, and your concubines;
Dare you be so much a traitor, to think
I'd marry with a public stallion,
A town bull.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Your highness —

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: No more? for the honour of this day I do
Conceal your faults and pardon 'em.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.l: Giotto, I shall prick your veins.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Volterre.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: What means these several parleys?

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I am to give you thanks (My lord) for your
Great care oth' public weal. You did implore
My haste to marriage, merely for your
Country's good, you yourself not guilty of,
Any hope to profit by it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Your excellence does me too much right.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And can your nature suffer you to do
Me wrong: you under value me, my birth
And title, for else a little foreign
Vanity, show in corrupted mixture
of unknown tongues; would not encourage thee
T'attempt our person, and so become our equal.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.l: Your highness will hold me in excuse.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Yes you've more deserved our mercy then
The rest — walk aside.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Comachio ▪

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Hey, I begin to prosper!

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: You are your country's father, chief of those
Whose zealous interest ith' common wealth,
Urged to entreat my first endeavours,
To help posterity with issue; yet
Prescribed yourself no share ith' benefit:
Fie my lord! how sinful has ambition
Made you? 'tis strange, that he, whom we have held
Our oracle, should conspire the death of
One so harmless as your nephew.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My gracious mistress:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: We know all; but in hope you'll not malign
Our next election, you taste our mercy.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: False Giotto, thou shalt suffer.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Signior de Pazzi.

sp.speaker: Paz.
sp.l: Hom! now I begin my reign: Duchess,
We know thy mind: thou wouldst protest thy great
Love unto our royal person. Contarini,
Thy speech and let's to bed, we'll have our subjects
Know our prompt desire to furnish them
With a lusty hire.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your lordship will please to hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Paz.
sp.l: First we would know thy lips. I say it is
Our will to buss thy highness.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: The fellows saucy, take him away.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: How now nephew? —

sp.speaker: Paz.
sp.l: 'Tis fine i'faith —

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Behold (Lords) your prince Foscari, Duke of
Parma, and of Mantua, now our lover,
Whom lately you supposed dismissed our court.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Indeed we see the golden fleece his order,
And a face like his, but yet his chin wants
part of his beard.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: I left that naked, more to disguise me
From your knowledge. And that our fame, (Which must
Out live our person) may give reply to those,
Who shall hereafter question it; know, we
Undertake this shape, to help us in discovery
Of all your souls and hearts; the better to
Enable us; how to dispose of each
Beneath our government.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: And I made secret promise, to bring you
To a court purged, and in clear health: your lords
Have all ta'en physic from my prescription.
Here I present 'em to you, penitent
And wise; for now they know themselves; which is
The best knowledge, and chief part of wisdom.
You are to grant their pardons for my sake.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: With great alacrity, and I banish
All their crimes from my remembrance.
sp.stage: They kneel, kiss his hand by turns.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Deprived of my revenge too!

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Then I am no judge now.

sp.speaker: Paz.
sp.l: 'Tis a new trick of state, continually
To shift great offices.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Ear I've made my cushion warm!

sp.speaker: Paz.
sp.l: No remedy, if I'm his favourite,
Thou shalt be my pimp, then thou'rt sure to rise.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Must we not be reconciled to my lord
Depazzi too?

sp.speaker: Paz.
sp.l: I forgive your highness, I.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: And I you, your love is soon requited:

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: I hope your excellence will pardon my
Rude intrusion into your acquaintance .
Her grace concealed this part of her design
From me. I never knew till now, that you
Were more than Giotto, the Florentine.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Madam, you are truly noble: you have
Merited our best assistance.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long Foscari, Duke of Mantua, and Parma.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This noise brings in Carintha.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Uneasy thoughts perplex her husband.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Make not rumour acquainted with
Your grief: as yet 'tis contained ith' knowledge
Of us four, I forgive his excellence
His sin 'gainst me. Make me your good example,
And forgive your wife her error.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Heaven has punished my ambition, it was
My own seeking. I'm content to suffer.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Then take your wife, and with assurance from
The faith of a true knight and prince, she doth
Retain that chastity she had, when first
I saw her. Now each wrinkled brow grows smooth;
And I begin my sovereignty: with hope
To give succession cause, still to prefer
This day, as chief within their calendar.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
